results.title: Always Goodbye cinema slide
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Sidney Lanfield
results.credit_line: ACMI has endeavoured to contact the owners of these objects since their deposit in 2015. Unfortunately this has been unsuccessful. We would welcome any information to identify the owners.
results.brief_description: Two glass sheets (one with slide imagery. A monochromatic emulsion then hand painted with coloured pigments or dye) / the other sheet glass only. TEXT on the slide reads: Mayfair at her feet - Scotland Yard on her trail Fascinating Elissa Landi in Always Goodbye A daring game of hearts and diamonds with Lewis Stone Paul Cavanagh For General Exhibition
results.creator_credit_for_label: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Sidney Lanfield

results.title: Alice Guy-Blaché
results.brief_description: Alice Guy-Blaché was a trailblazing French director, producer and screenwriter, and the co-founder and artistic director of her own film studio. She made hundreds of films between during her career, including the first fictional film with a scripted narrative, La Fée aux Choux

constellations_primary.name: Lost and found
constellations_primary.description: Blossoming from Alice Guy Blaché’s The Cabbage-Patch Fairy, this Constellation explores the impermanence and enduring nature of the moving image.

results.description:
Alice Guy-Blaché was a trailblazing French director, producer and screenwriter, and the co-founder and artistic director of her own film studio, Solax. She made hundreds of films between 1896 and the 1920s, including the first fictional film with a scripted narrative, La Fée aux Choux (The Cabbage Fairy, 1896).

Guy-Blaché later experimented with early synchronised sound, colour and special effects, often filming on location with hundreds of extras. In 1912 she made A Fool and His Money, widely believed to be the first film to have an all–African American cast.

To find our more about Alice Guy-Blaché, rent Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché on our streaming platform, Cinema 3.
description_for_label:
Alice Guy-Blaché was a trailblazing French director, producer and screenwriter, and the co-founder and artistic director of her own film studio, Solax. She made hundreds of films between 1896 and the 1920s, including the first fictional film with a scripted narrative, La Fée aux Choux (The Cabbage Fairy, 1896).

Guy-Blaché later experimented with early synchronised sound, colour and special effects, often filming on location with hundreds of extras. In 1912 she made A Fool and His Money, widely believed to be the first film to have an all–African American cast.

results.title: Alibi Ike cinema slide
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures and Ray Enright
results.credit_line: ACMI has endeavoured to contact the owners of these objects since their deposit in 2015. Unfortunately this has been unsuccessful. We would welcome any information to identify the owners.
results.brief_description: Two glass sheets: one glass only and the other with slide imagery which has a monochromatic emulsion that has then been hand painted with coloured pigments or dye. TEXT on the slide reads: Joe E. Brown & Ruth Donnelly ‘He’s ‘Dizzy!’ ‘He’s ‘Daffy!’ A Laff Riot with a Brand-New Twist! “Alibi Ike” For General Exhibition Gunn Slide Gum edged tape reads: Gunn Slide 9 Collins Place, Melb. Cen

results.title: Albert and David Maysles filming Big Edie and Little Edie in Grey Gardens
results.brief_description: Dziga Vertov’s kino-pravda (“film truth”) concept was premised on the camera’s ability to reveal truth. It inspired both cinéma vérité and direct cinema, which informed Albert and David Maysles’ intimate ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style and Agnès Varda’s intimate portraits of society and herself.
results.title_for_label: Albert and David Maysles filming Big Edie and Little Edie in Grey Gardens
results.description: Documentarians develop camera techniques to access, interpret and compose notions of truth. Dziga Vertov’s kino-pravda (“film truth”) concept was premised on the camera’s ability to reveal truth. In the 1960s, it inspired the development of both cinéma vérité (“truthful cinema”) and direct cinema, which informed Albert and David Maysles’ intimate ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style and Agnès Varda’s use of a handheld camera to create a portrait of society and herself.
description_for_label: Documentarians develop camera techniques to access, interpret and compose notions of truth. Dziga Vertov’s kino-pravda (“film truth”) concept was premised on the camera’s ability to reveal truth. In the 1960s, it inspired the development of both cinéma vérité (“truthful cinema”) and direct cinema, which informed Albert and David Maysles’ intimate ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style and Agnès Varda’s use of a handheld camera to create a portrait of society and herself.
